title: Ticket #3850: condor should publish live job i/o statistics
description:
Modern linux kernels accurately track the total io (read_bytes and write_bytes) of a process, as documented here: http://git.kernel.org/cgit/linux/kernel/git/torvalds/linux.git/tree/Documentation/filesystems/proc.txt?id=HEAD#n1491

It would be nice if Condor updated and published this data for each job periodically.

E.g., I want to know the i/o rate (e.g., KB/s over the last 60s) for each job, so I can identify i/o-heavy jobs in my pool -- or maybe for longer periods like 1h, stuck jobs.

I am simulating this now with a very very hacky startd cron script which scrapes the process table to identify all condor_starters, then scrapes their command-line arguments to associate each one with its slotid, then identifies each starter's children, and then runs pidstat (which just looks in /proc/pid/io) on each child, and then sums the info and stuff it into a slotid_ prefixed machine ad attribute. But this is ugly and doesn't get saved into the job's history.

2013-Aug-12 21:53:38 by bbockelm:
To chime in -

This should be a fairly straightforward improvement. We already have the attributes defined from the cgroups work; we just need to read in the statistics in a different way.

Would be about 6 hours of work for someone interested in learning the procd code.

2013-Nov-04 16:53:37 by eje:
Something that operates similar to ImageSize today, but that records ClassAds maybe something like: 

JobBytesRead
JobBytesWritten
JobReadSysCalls
JobWriteSysCalls

...and ideally also...

JobReadOpsPerSecond
JobWriteOpsPerSecond

Where you could develop throttling policies at a DAGMan management level around concurrency limiting or potentially evicting jobs based on stats like number-of-jobs * writes-per-second.

2014-Mar-07 12:50:25 by eje:
An observation about tracking rate information: this information is compiled by the starter, which updates at a default frequency of 5 min, and then passes through the shadow, whose default update rate is 15 minutes.

This double-layered latency, combined with large-ish default update intervals, has a possible impact on semantics for rate info. To wit: it doesn't mean much to compile rates over last 60 seconds, unless you (re)configure startd update interval to <= 60s. And all stat updates to the wider universe are subsequently rate limited by the shadow's update interval.

My current plan is to define rates as being "change in reported cgroup i/o metrics since last update, divided by the seconds since last update."

A possible alternative is to use the stats lib, however imo that seems somewhat heavy-weight for rate stats where sampling resolution is limited by typical update times in the >= minute range.

2014-Mar-09 10:41:14 by eje:
Actually, some notion of 'recent' i/o activity is probably useful, which would warrant stats lib support.

2014-Mar-17 11:49:02 by eje: 
proposed attributes are:

BlockReadKbytes   # these 1st two already exist
BlockWriteKbytes
BlockReads
BlockWrites

The above are maintained via the generic_stats lib, and so analogous to the scheduler stats, you can also turn on:

RecentBlockReadKbytes
RecentBlockWriteKbytes
RecentBlockReads
RecentBlockWrites

Also like the schedd, the 'recent' windowing is controlled by:
STATISTICS_WINDOW_SECONDS_STARTER = 60
STATISTICS_WINDOW_QUANTUM_STARTER = 15

I think this would also work:
STARTER.STATISTICS_WINDOW_SECONDS
STARTER.STATISTICS_WINDOW_QUANTUM

There will be no direct 'rate attributes'.  To get reads/sec or bytes/sec, the user can divide 'Recent*' by RecentWindowMaxStarter

The following may be advertised if configured:
StatsLastUpdateTimeStarter
StatsLifetimeStarter
RecentStatsLifetimeStarter
RecentWindowMaxStarter
RecentStatsTickTimeStarter

turning "all of the above" on happens by configuring:

STATISTICS_TO_PUBLISH = STARTER:2ALL

2014-Mar-17 18:24:23 by eje:
I've been discussing file i/o with customer in the background. They've got a definite interest in tracking NFS related i/o, which is also not covered by the blkio controller.

Traversing /proc/<pid>/io to obtain /proc's version of io stats and advertise those is a reasonable option. That's a bit more work, and has the problem of being able to miss process sub-trees that fall between sampling intervals, but it can serve as a complementary source of i/o stats. If we did that, it might be useful to make it optional. Maybe 'verbose-only', or something like it. Might also deserve its own separate ticket.

2014-Mar-19 17:44:57 by johnkn:
CODE_REVIEW: partial. I'm still looking, but one thing I see is that I think m_previous_usage isn't needed in vanilla_proc.cpp. The stats_entry_recent<> template has a class override for += which you are currently using. but it also has an override for = which I think you should be using.

have a look at generic_stats.h line 926.

the stats_entry_recent<> will let you just set the absolute value and it will calculate the recent change in value automatically.

Also, I think if you stored BlockReadBytes instead of KBytes, an int64_t would be plenty big enough and you would never need to worry about error accumulation. This would be better than using double because doubles have their own form of error accumulation once the base value you are adding to gets large, a double will begin to accumulate error sooner than an int64_t would.

2014-Mar-20 15:09:40 by eje:
I excised the m_previous_usage since it's redundant, just used '=' instead of '+='

Consensus to keep BlockReadKbytes and BlockWriteKbytes as-is, on the grounds of preserving legacy behavior.

2014-Mar-21 13:07:27 by johnkn:
I don't see a commit for this change?

It occurred to me that we could track bytes in the statistics using int64_t, but set the publication level of those longs to IF_VERBOSEPUB and the publish name BlockReadBytes. Then add code to ..Stats::Publish class to generate the Kbytes values 

   ...
   Pool.Publish(ad, flags);
   if ((flags & IF_PUBLEVEL) > 0) {
      ad.Assign("BlockReadKBytes", this->BlockReadBytes.value / 1024);
      ad.Assign("RecentBlockReadKBytes", this->BlockReadBytes.recent / 1024);
   }

2014-Mar-21 16:28:02 by johnkn:
CODE_REVIEW: stats stuff looks good to me. I'm not qualified to judge the cgroups code, so I'm transferring this ticket to gthain.

2014-Mar-25 15:10:37 by gthain:
CODE REVIEW cgroup block I/O looks good to me.

2014-Mar-30 13:08:54 by eje:
In my downstream testing, the publication of the new BlockReadBytes and BlockWriteBytes was getting corrupted by downcasting to 4-byte integer somewhere in the path from the Starter to the Job ads in the scheduler. Downstream I changed the publication flags of those to IF_NEVER, as the "KBytes" versions stay small enough to work at larger i/o values.

I haven't yet tested whether this same problem happens on the newer 8.1 code.
